dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Four iPhone owners from 2011 are finally getting their day in court, and it's all about that 30% App Store commission.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Four iPhone owners from twenty eleven are finally getting their day in court, and it's all about that thirty percent App Store commission.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court. Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the Supreme Court just ruled 5-4 that the suit can move forward. Justice Kavanaugh really called out Apple's argument, uh, calling it arbitrary and unprincipled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the Supreme Court just ruled five to four that the suit can move forward. Justice Kavanaugh really called out Apple's argument, uh, calling it arbitrary and unprincipled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he said it was basically a way to gerrymander themselves out of lawsuits. But Apple's standing by their position—they say developers set the prices, not them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he said it was basically a way to gerrymander themselves out of lawsuits. But Apple's standing by their position-they say developers set the prices, not them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples line-drawing does not make a lot of sense, other than as a way to gerrymander Apple out of this and similar lawsuits, Kavanaugh wrote. Developers set the price they want to charge for their app and Apple has no role in that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is true for free apps, but when there's in-app purchases or subscriptions, that's where Apple takes a cut. And Spotify and Netflix have been vocal about how unfair they find that fee structure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is true for free apps, but when there's in-app purchases or subscriptions, that's where Apple takes a cut. And Spotify and Netflix have been vocal about how unfair they find that fee structure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement. The only instance where Apple shares in revenue is if the developer chooses to sell digital services through the App Store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not small change either—the App Store brought in something like $3.6 billion last quarter alone. That's a huge part of their services revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not small change either-the App Store brought in something like three point six dollars billion last quarter alone. That's a huge part of their services revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And developers have earned over $120 billion from it over the years, so it's a two-way street, but the power dynamic is definitely skewed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And developers have earned over one hundred twenty dollars billion from it over the years, so it's a two-way street, but the power dynamic is definitely skewed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially when you consider companies like Netflix are now bypassing iTunes payments entirely to avoid giving Apple a share.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially when you consider companies like Netflix are now bypassing iTunes payments entirely to avoid giving Apple a share.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Netflix said it would no longer allow new customers to pay for their monthly subscription fees through iTunes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Spotify filed a complaint in Europe too, accusing Apple of acting like both a player and a referee. It's a pretty strong criticism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Spotify filed a complaint in Europe too, accusing Apple of acting like both a player and a referee. It's a pretty strong criticism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So this ruling doesn't just affect Apple—it could set a precedent for other digital marketplaces like Google Play or Amazon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this ruling doesn't just affect Apple-it could set a precedent for other digital marketplaces like Google Play or Amazon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Consumer advocates are saying platforms might have to rethink how they operate, to allow more competition and maybe lower prices for users.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Consumer advocates are saying platforms might have to rethink how they operate, to allow more competition and maybe lower prices for users.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild to think how much the iPhone has changed everything—entertainment, shopping, everything—and now the very ecosystem that made it successful is under legal scrutiny.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild to think how much the iPhone has changed everything-entertainment, shopping, everything-and now the very ecosystem that made it successful is under legal scrutiny.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with Tim Cook calling the App Store a revolution, this case could redefine what that revolution looks like moving forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with Tim Cook calling the App Store a revolution, this case could redefine what that revolution looks like moving forward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indeed, CEO Tim Cook once hailed it as a revolution that has changed our world.
